seriesJson.title: Man and the multitude
seriesJson.description: A lecture series commemorating the centennial of the University of Illinois.

node.title: Peter Viereck discussion, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a discussion of Peter Viereck's lecture, "The Fight for Creativity and Personality in a Machine Age." Additional speakers include Gary Adelman, Billy Jackson, Royal MacDonald, Joseph Gusfield, Karl Wallace, all of the University of Illinois; and James McGarrell of Indiana University.

node.title: Peter Viereck discussion, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a discussion of Peter Viereck's lecture, "The Fight for Creativity and Personality in a Machine Age." Additional speakers include Gary Adelman, Billy Jackson, Royal MacDonald, Joseph Gusfield, Karl Wallace, all of the University of Illinois; and James McGarrell of Indiana University.

node.title: Peter Viereck, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a lecture by Peter Viereck, Mount Holyoke College and Pulitzer Prize winner, on "The Fight for Creativity and Personality in a Machine Age."

node.title: Peter Viereck, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a lecture by Peter Viereck, Mount Holyoke College and Pulitzer Prize winner, on "The Fight for Creativity and Personality in a Machine Age."

node.title: Daniel J. Boorstin discussion, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a discussion of Daniel J. Boorstin's lecture, "The Culture of Communications."Additional speakers include Rita Simon, James W. Carey, H.E. Gulley, all of University of Illinois; and Fred S. Siebert, Michigan State University.

node.title: Daniel J. Boorstin discussion, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a discussion of Daniel J. Boorstin's lecture, "The Culture of Communications."Additional speakers include Rita Simon, James W. Carey, H.E. Gulley, all of University of Illinois; and Fred S. Siebert, Michigan State University.

node.title: Daniel J. Boorstin, part two
node.description: This program, the second of two parts, presents Daniel J. Boorstin, University of Chicago, on "The Culture of Communications."

node.title: Daniel J. Boorstin, part one
node.description: This program, the first of two parts, presents Daniel J. Boorstin, University of Chicago, on "The Culture of Communications."

node.title: Discussion of Long and Gustafson lectures, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a discussion of lectures by Norton Long and James Gustafson. Speakers include Morris Davis, Benjamin Garrison, Harry Tiebout (all of the University of Illinois); Marcus Singer, University of Wisconsin; and Richard Brandt, University of Michigan.

node.title: Discussion of Long and Gustafson lectures, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a discussion of lectures by Norton Long and James Gustafson. Speakers include Morris Davis, Benjamin Garrison, Harry Tiebout (all of the University of Illinois); Marcus Singer, University of Wisconsin; and Richard Brandt, University of Michigan.

node.title: Norton Long and James Gustafson, part one
node.description: This program, the first of two parts, presents lectures by Norton Long of Brandeis University on "Political Reality and Individual Responsibility" and James Gustafson of Yale University on "Morality and Religion: Sustaining or Restraining?"

node.title: Norton Long and James Gustafson, part two
node.description: This program, the second of two parts, presents lectures by Norton Long of Brandeis University on "Political Reality and Individual Responsibility" and James Gustafson of Yale University on "Morality and Religion: Sustaining or Restraining?"

node.title: George Wald discussion, part one
node.description: This program, the first of two parts, presents a discussion of a George Wald lecture. Speakers include Ross Ashby; Heinz von Foerster; Melvin Sabshin; and David Pines, all of the University of Illinois.

node.title: George Wald discussion, part two
node.description: This program, the second of two parts, presents a discussion of a George Wald lecture. Speakers include Ross Ashby; Heinz von Foerster; Melvin Sabshin; and David Pines, all of the University of Illinois.

node.title: George Wald, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a lecture by George Wald, Harvard University, on "The Human Enterprise: A Scientist's View."

node.title: George Wald, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a lecture by George Wald, Harvard University, on "The Human Enterprise: A Scientist's View."

node.title: Constantinos Doxiadis, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a lecture by Constantinos Doxiadis, prominent architect, city planner, and winner of the Aspen Award, on "Man in the City of the Future."

node.title: Constantinos Doxiadis, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a lecture by Constantinos Doxiadis, prominent architect, city planner, and winner of the Aspen Award, on "Man in the City of the Future."

node.title: Galbraith discussion, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a discussion of John Kenneth Galbraith's lecture, with Norman Graebner; James Heins; Martin Wagner; Margaret Reid of University of Chicago; and Robert Eisner of Northwestern University.

node.title: Galbraith discussion, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a discussion of John Kenneth Galbraith's lecture, with Norman Graebner; James Heins; Martin Wagner; Margaret Reid of University of Chicago; and Robert Eisner of Northwestern University.

node.title: John Kenneth Galbraith, part two
node.description: This program presents the second part of a lecture by John Kenneth Galbraith, professor of economics, Harvard University, on "Individual and Organization in the Industrial State."

node.title: John Kenneth Galbraith, part one
node.description: This program presents the first part of a lecture by John Kenneth Galbraith, professor of economics, Harvard University, on "Individual and Organization in the Industrial State."
